technical_features.source_sentence: The maximum adsorption capacity obtained from Langmuir fitting was equal to 146.28 mg P/g.
Our 1/n value obtained for phosphate adsorption by BC-5 was equal to 0.41.
The Ca content in the BC-5 sample was 7.72%.
The highest adsorption efficiency (equal to 93.33%) was achieved at pH = 11.
PO₄³⁻ was complexed by biochar’s Ca²⁺ yielding hydroxyapatite.
SO₄²⁻ inhibited phosphate adsorption by the BC-5 material: the corresponding adsorption capacities decreased by 2.79%.

qualitative_insights.main_objective: Develop Ca-enriched biochar from sheep manure and oyster shells for efficient phosphate adsorption in wastewater treatment while utilizing agricultural waste.
key_methodology_summary: Pyrolysis of sheep manure at 500°C under N₂ atmosphere
Chemical modification with oyster shell-derived Ca via HCl treatment
Adsorption experiments under varying pH, phosphate concentrations, and coexisting ions
Characterization using SEM-EDS, FTIR, XRD, and ICP-OES
primary_findings_conclusions: Maximum adsorption capacity of 146.28 mg P/g (Langmuir model)
94% adsorption efficiency at 50 mg P/L concentration
Primary mechanism: Ca²⁺-PO₄³⁻ complexation forming hydroxyapatite
Optimal performance at pH >7 (89.5-93.3 mg P/g)
limitations_discussed_by_authors: Reduced adsorption capacity under acidic conditions (pH <7)
Potential interference from NO₃⁻ and SO₄²⁻ anions
Decreased surface area post-Ca modification (4.74 m²/g vs 5.14 m²/g)
future_work_suggested_by_authors: Scale-up production for practical wastewater treatment applications
Optimize oyster shell-to-biochar ratios for cost efficiency
novelty_significance_claim: First use of oyster shell waste as calcium source for biochar modification
Dual waste valorization strategy for agricultural byproducts
Competitive adsorption capacity vs chemically modified biochars
key_tables_figures_present: Figures 1-2 (SEM/EDS of unmodified vs modified biochar)
